p: The influenza virus was isolated from the nasal discharge of infected patients by Wilson Smith, Sir Christopher Andrews, and Sir Patrick Laidlaw in 1933 [ 115]. This isolation procedure was used to develop inactivated influenza vaccines, which are grown on the chorio-allantoid membrane of embryonated eggs [ 116] or in cell culture [ 76], purified through centrifugation, and chemically inactivated [ 117]. Split virus and subunit inactivated vaccines followed the development of whole-virus inactivated influenza vaccines in the 1960s and 1970s [ 118]. These vaccines are used more than whole-virus influenza vaccines due to their reduced reactogenicity [ 76].
